item.title: Notes on Arya et al., 2000
item.description:
The paper: Arya, A., J. Fellingham, Jonathan Glover , D. Schroeder, and Gilbert Strang. “Inferring Transactions from Financial Statements.” Contemporary Accounting Research vol. 17, (January 01, 2000): 366-385.

The Question

Given a set of financial statement \(x\), what is the “best guess” of the underlying transaction vector \(y\)?

The Solution

Four steps to form the solution:

  1. Build a algebric representation for accounting process: \(Ay=x\) (\(A\) is the double entry matrix)
  2. Identify the fundamental subspaces of \(A\).
  3. Given \(x\), solve all possible \(y\) that satisfy \(Ay=x\).
  4. Given the reader’s priors over \(y\), derive the conditional mean of the consistent \(y\) vectors.

item.title: Useful Websites
item.description:
I usually ran into some really interesting, useful and cool websites that want to share with you, who are willing to spend time reading my website:) I hope this is an archival that I will update frequently.

Learning Resources

  • Learn Empirical Research in Accounting: Tools and Methods by Ian D. Gow and Tongqing Ding
  • Learn RCT from Running Randomized Evaluations: A Practical Guide
  • Read Bit By Bit: Social Research in the Digital Age by Matthew J. Salganik
  • Learn Causal Inference: The Mix Tape by Scott Cunningham
  • Game Theory Books by Ariel Rubinstein

Useful Tools

  • Using Research Rabbit to searching for relevant literature. The network and visualization looks really nice.

Dataset

  • Visit China Data Institue (subscription required) for Chinese geographical and other data.
  • Software Repository for Accounting and Finance by Loughran-McDonald
  • Word Embeddings for Historical Text

Coding

  • Data Analysis Examples in UCLA Statistical Methods and Data Analytics
  • Library of Statistical Techniques by Nick Huntington-Klein
  • DiD Software packages by Asjad Naqvi

Giants’ Shoulder

  • Visit Yihui Xie’s Homepage for everything about R Programming (This website is based on his tutorial!)
  • Visit Sangmin Simon Oh’s Homepage - it is fantastic and full of insights and useful resources for PhD students. He starts to run a new blog page Better Know A Dataset (BKAD) that showcases interesting datasets, highlighting noteworthy patterns and analyses.
  • For students by Xiang Sun

Pre-doc

  • Pre-doc Job Posting on NBER
  • Econ RA Guide
  • See Schlauch and Startz’s The path to an economics PhD
  • Alvin Christian’s Pre-doc Memo
  • Pre-Doctoral Training Opportunities listed on Wharton website
  • RA Manual by Matthew Gentzkow

When you are boring…

  • Read some spurious correlations by Tyler Vigen
  • Find the Beamer theme you want to use for your next presentation (I hate beamer tho)
  • Browse for data visualization idea at PolicyViz to remind yourself the life of an “Artist”
  • Visit this amazing color website to find great Chinese Colors
  • Search for the occurrence of a word or phrase in Google Books Ngram Viewer
  • Read this super cool FT article about transformer (subscription needed)
  • Visit Opportunity Insights to see research about equality, migration, mobility and opportunity etc.
  • Try quick LDA topic modeling here
  • Run t-SNE here to see the world in different angle
  • See artwork mapped by t-SNE by Google Arts & Culture or simply Color Explorer
  • See Chinese Philosophy in a graph

When you are boring and want nothing about research…

  • See the real-time thunderstorms here

item.title: What's the best way to build an efficient research workflow?
item.description:
As the question mark in title indicated, I personally haven’t find THE best way to do so. There is still a long way to go. But influenced by many people, I thing Github + Dropbox/Cluster works perfect.

Github serves as a code hub where you can do version control and collaborate with co-authors. You can easily track all the changes on code. Dropbox or a computer cluster serves as cloud to store all the huge datasets.
